comment._content: One of these trams of this vintage down at loftus in the museum. [?] -- Seen on your photo stream. (?)

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: We had a lot of interest from our Archives Outside friends and have established a c.1900 date for this photo. It is a wonderful image of the hustle and bustle of early Sydney - with trams and pre-traffic snarls.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
Just compare it to Spit junction today

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper/6140401872/in/photostream/]

See more recent pictures below

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/30265340@N00]  The tram standing in Spit Road (middle background) is a C-class tramcar as is the car just passing out of the frame on the right towards Mosman - both power cars. The tram standing right in the junction would appear to be a non-powered trailer car. In the distance, heading towards the Spit, beyond the points,can be seen a C-class and trailer set.

comment.author: 75983496@N00
comment._content: a Century of NSW tramcars volume 1,NChinn K McCarthey does go into detail on the early North Sydney System because the cars it covers in the book are the earliest one as in the photo,long out of print though,,State libary only place youll see it nowdays id say,but they have it

comment.author: 75983496@N00
comment._content: this photo could be the day of the opening of the line to the Spit??

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75983496@N00] Not sure about the opening, but there does seem to be a bit of bunting over on the left - I have a copy of the book and I'll check the dates and report!

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/75983496@N00] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/30265340@N00] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] 

Terry, you are correct! Construction of the line between between Spit Junction and The Spit was completed on 27 October 1900, and the official opening was held on Saturday 3 November 1900. It was estimated that 2,000 people were present at the event. The line was opened by EW Sullivan, Minsiter for Public Works.

comment.author: 75983496@N00
comment._content: thanks John,I was sure id seen this or a simular photo somwhere else,and I was certain the spit extention opening was the feature

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75983496@N00] Apparently some 4,500 passengers used the line between 27 October (the completion date) and 3 November 1900 (opening day) - not bad for a new bit of tramline 'so' far from the city centre! Such was the lure of harbour views afforded along the route. Now we sit in our cars, breathing each others fumes, and the RTA spends millions trying to speed up the traffic. Progress! The trams have long gone.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/terrycrowley] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] After reading your comments I revisited the blog post and it looks like we dated it to the opening ceremony day, 3 Nov 1900. This confirms it, thank you! * Photo Investigator image * blog post AB

comment.author: 61713553@N00
comment._content: Hi - we've added this photo & dating to the Facebook page for 'The People's Junction' - a project to develop a Masterplan to revitalise the junction. Thank you! www.facebook.com/peoplesjunction

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mosmanlibrary] It's a pleasure to be able to assist in a small way. Spit Junction is madness at the moment, especially with all the RTA's contributions!

comment.author: 90440714@N04
comment._content: I'm in the process of building a D class Tram for my own tramway. I will be having a centre pole though and ont off to the side as the early trams had on this route. The D class trams were the last word in cumfort and style on the "Spitpt Junction to the Spit" in the early years of last century. Though I'm not sure where trams to the Spit terminated before the harbour bridge, probably Milsons point trevs-tramway.blogspot.com.au
